body:
I currently do like `ctrl-C, ctrl-D` to break out of a `--more--`. It seems like this combination removes the first character of the next line. Thus removing the `` ` `` of the macro. I tried just adding a space in front of the md5 but I guess there are weird escape characters that I can't see as well.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15164633/44378580-fc20e580-a4cf-11e8-82c5-abc4e01685a4.png)

If you leave more on, it should be set to

```
local usermore: set more
// stuff
set more `usermore'
```

My idea is to set more by default when starting the kernel. Then if someone has a `more` option at the top of their script, that will override the kernel.

I'm still struggling to figure out the ideal way to send a break to the console... Working with the raw Stata console itself:
- Doing <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>-<kbd>D</kbd> just scrolls down `pagesize`
- Doing <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>-<kbd>C</kbd> on its own does nothing
- Doing <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>-<kbd>D</kbd> then <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>-<kbd>C</kbd> scrolls once and then does visibly nothing
- Doing <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>-<kbd>C</kbd> then <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>-<kbd>D</kbd> successfully sends a break, but it appears to remove the first character of the next line. It appears that <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>-<kbd>D</kbd> by itself removes the following character when not in a break:
![stata_ctrl_d](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15164633/44410293-155a7e00-a532-11e8-97fb-4c32791db5be.gif)
- Pressing <kbd>q</kbd> works in the Stata console, but doesn't seem to send a break with `child.send('q')` or `child.sendline('q')`, the latter of which also sends an end of line character.

@mcaceresb Any ideas?
If you prepend a dot to `` `hash'``, does that break stuff on other systems? If I send a single dot as a command nothing happens, so you can do ``. `md5'`` or would that have the same issue?

Prepending a dot didn't actually change anything. It was sent as 
```
. list
. `10ae9fc7d453b0dd525d0edf2ede7961'
```
(that second dot usually wouldn't be there)

But below in the log I still see
```
     +----------------------------------------------------------------------+
 39. | make              |  price | mpg | rep78 | headroom | trunk | weight |
     | Olds Omega        |  4,181 |  19 |     3 |      4.5 |    14 |  3,370 |
     |----------------------------------------------------------------------|
     |   --Break--
r(1);

. 10ae9fc7d453b0dd525d0edf2ede7961'
10ae9fc7d453b0dd525d0edf2ede7961 is not a valid command name
r(199);

. _StataKernelCompletions
```

It seems like the main issue is actually that when I break `more`, it doesn't _always_ show
```
--Break--
r(1);
```
Sometimes it just finishes. So when I set the `send_break` function to:
```py
    def send_break(self, child):
        """Send break to Stata

        Tell Stata to stop current execution. This is used when `expect` hits
        more and for a KeyboardInterrupt. I've found that ctrl-C, ctrl-D is the
        most consistent way for the console version to stop execution.

        Args:
            child (pexpect.spawn): pexpect instance to watch for successful
                break.
        """
        if self.config.get('execution_mode') == 'console':
            child.sendcontrol('c')
            # child.sendcontrol('d')
        else:
            self.automate('UtilSetStataBreak')

        try:
            child.expect('--Break--', timeout=1)
            child.expect(r'r\(1\);', timeout=1)
            # When sent inside `include`, two sets of --Break-- are shown
            child.expect('--Break--', timeout=0.3)
            child.expect(r'r\(1\);', timeout=0.3)
        except pexpect.TIMEOUT:
            pass

        # There are two newlines before the next period. Remove one of them
        child.expect('\r?\n')
```
it doesn't get caught with `more`. However, there are definitely some commands for which Stata does produce a `--break--` but that take a while. Especially if Stata is stuck in C code that it can't break out of quickly. And I don't want to set a 1 sec timeout for seeing `--Break--`. But idk what else to expect for.
On detecting more, can you quickly send a couple of `<CR>` right after `<C-c>`?
You mean `\r\n`s?
Or just `\r`?
Mmm. The keypress 'enter'. Does `\r` have the same effect? The issue is that if I press enter in the console it does give me a new prompt, but on more it does scroll it.
Is that what you meant?

Yes, but I should've seen it coming.  `--more--` is eating `` ` `` bc any key press will scroll more while in more. One hack to try is to put a bunch of "\r\n" between `` `md5'`` and the code, but that feels rather unsatisfying.
Ok I don't fully understand... Why isn't `--more--` broken out of with <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>-<kbd>C</kbd> + <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>-<kbd>D</kbd>?

Have you tried `q` instead of `<C-c>`?

More scrolls are controlled by `pagesize`. I don't think there's anything special about `<C-d>`; any key after `<C-c>` would do, which is why `` ` `` gets eaten. The console will scroll more by `min(pagesize, console height)` as best I can tell. However, after `<C-c>` it scrolls a line at a time for some reason. If there is more input, the lines are the next input line, `--Break--`, `r(1);`, and the next line. If there is no more input, the lines are just the last 3.

At least that is how it is on my system. If pagesize is 4 or higher, as best I can tell, `q` will correctly break more. However, by that time I suppose `--more--` will have already eaten the backtick for the hash...
Whenever I tried `q` it didn't seem to work. You're welcome to try it out. Just use `child.sendline('q')` instead of `child.sendcontrol('c')`.

I think the main issue here isn't the immediate sending of the break and rather the expecting for `--Break--`. Because it works fine when you do
```
sysuse auto
set more on
list
```
because it correctly produces a break for that.

It just doesn't work with 
```
more
```
because that scrolls and ends before it can produce a `--Break--`.
What seems to work for me is to add `child.sendline('error 1')` after `<C-c>` and `<C-d>` to make sure there is a break message in case the scrolling fails.
Ok, I'll test with that. You should keep testing it and let me know if you get hiccups still. Are you using it as your daily driver yet?
As of today. I have my pull requests merged locally and a snazzy dark theme for qtconsole. Will post any hiccups I encounter.
How did you get the dark theme?

I found 
https://bitbucket.org/joon/color-schemes-for-jupyter-qt-console
https://www.reddit.com/r/IPython/comments/3hfflo/jupyter_qtconsole_colors/
https://github.com/dunovank/jupyter-themes

which I'll add to parts of the docs about customization.

The qtconsole even works with Fira Code font! Granted I'll be doing everything in Atom, which I already have customized.

I make a file and replaced `stata.py` in `/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pygments/styles`

```stata
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-
"""
    pygments.styles.stata
    ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

    Dark stata theme
"""

from pygments.style import Style
from pygments.token import Keyword, Name, Comment, String, Error, \
    Number, Operator, Whitespace, Generic


class StataStyle(Style):
    """
    Style inspired by Stata's do-file editor. Note this is not meant
    to be a complete style. It's merely meant to mimic Stata's do file
    editor syntax highlighting.
    """

    default_style = ''
    background_color = "#232629"
    highlight_color = "#49483e"

    styles = {
        Whitespace:            '#bbbbbb',
        Error:                 'bg:#e3d2d2 #a61717',
        String:                '#51cc99',
        Number:                '#4FB8CC',
        Operator:              '',
        Keyword:               'bold #7799cc',
        Keyword.Constant:      '',
        Comment:               'italic #999999',
        Name.Variable:         'bold #7AB4DB',
        Name.Variable.Global:  'bold #BE646C',
        Generic.Prompt:        '#ffffff',
    }
```

Then `jupyter qtconsole --kernel stata --style='stata'`
I also customized the prompt to be a less annoying green, but that's a CSS style sheet.
@mcaceresb have you had any issues with your resolving of `more` in the past two weeks?
Not sure; I think I did because I commented it out and added `set more off` to the startup commands.
